article:
'Proliferative Vitreo Retinopathy' ('PVR') is a disease that develops as a
complication, secondary to rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. PVR occurs in
about 8â10% of patients undergoing primary retinal detachment surgery and
prevents the successful surgical repair of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
PVR can be treated with surgery to reattach the detached retina but the visual
outcome of the surgery is very poor. {{cite journal |author=Leaver PK
|title=Proliferative vitreoretinopathy |journal=British Journal of Ophthalmology
|year=1995 |volume=79 |pages=871â872 |doi=10.1136/bjo.79.10.871 |pmid=7488570
|issue=10 |pmc=505283 }} {{cite web |author=
|url=http://www.retinatexas.com/vitreoretinopathy.html |title=Proliferative
Vitreoretinopathy |publisher=Retina and Vitreous of Texas |year= |accessdate=2009-05-
28 }}

PVR was originally referred to as 'massive vitreous retraction' and then as
'massive periretinal proliferation'. The name Proliferative vitreo retinopathy
was provided in 1989 by the Silicone Oil Study group. The name is derived from
proliferation (by the retinal pigment epithelial and glial cells) and vitreo
retinopathy to include the tissues which are affected, namely the vitreous humor
(or simply vitreous) and the retina. {{cite journal |author=Ceron OM and
Arroyo JG |title=Better Outcomes May Be Ahead for PVR
|url=http://www.revophth.com/index.asp?page=1_14133.htm |journal=Review of
Ophthalmology |volume=16 |page=1 |year=2009 |accessdate=2009-05-29 }}
